div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: Sudan Express Mail Service (Via Suez and Port Sudan)
div.p: Three Days to Khartoum
By `KHEDIVIAL MAIL EXPRESS S.S. "PRINCE ABBAS" and " EL KAHIRA " and SUDAN GOVERNMENT RAILWAYS "Trains de Luxe."
Departures from SUEZ DOCKS every WEDNESDAY 5 p.m. after arrival of 11 a.m. Train from Cairo, with Through Carriages to alongside steamer.
Special Sudan Government Train de Luxe with Sleeping and Dining Cars, awaits steamer's arrival at PORT SUDAN, FRIDAY EVENINGS, arriving KHARTOUM 8 p.m.
SATURDAYS. Returning from KHARTOUM, the Special Train leaves TUESDAYS 9.15 p.m. arriving alongside steamer at PORT SUDAN WEDNESDAY EVENINGS.
Steamer is timed to reach SUEZ SATURDAYS, to connect with 5.40 p.m. train to Cairo.

Further particulars may be obtained from any of KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE'S Agencies or from Principal Tourist Agencies by whom Circular Tickets are issued to Khartoum by the Nile, returning by Red Sea Express Service or Vice-Versa.

div.head: Death
div.p: PHILLIPS. — On Friday, December 27th, 1007, at Cairn, Gwyneth Helen Powell Phillips. only child of Dr. and Mrs. Llewellyn Phillips, aged two years and four months. The funeral took place on Satunlay 28th, Holy Innocents Day, in the old cemetery, Cairo.

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: An English Daily Newspaper, Established in 1880.
Editor & Manager: R. Snelling.
Price: One Piastre Tariff.
MONDAY, DECEMBER 30, 1907.

div.head: Pharaohs' Road to The Sudan
div.p: The old high road, forty-four centuries old, that led from Egypt to the Sudan, is the subject of an article by Mr. Weigall, Chief Inspector of the Egyptian Department of Antiquities in Blackwood's Magazine for December. As many of our readers, when visiting Assouan where the highway begins, would like to see the road the Pharaohs followed from the earliest ages in their various conquests of the Sudan, we will give the following extract from the article, to show how easily it can be reached. Mr. Weigall says :—

One would have thought that after four thousand four hundred years it would have utterly disappeared ; but this is not the case. Let the visitor to Aswan step out some afternoon from the hall of his hotel, where the string band throbs in his ears and the latest Parisian gowns shimmer before his eyes, and let him, take boat to the little western bay behind the ruins of Elephantine Here in the late afternoon the long blue shadows fall, and he may walk in coolness over the sand towards the monastery which stands on the higher ground before him. At the top of the hills to his left he will presently see, some distance away, a Iarge isolated boulder near the tomb of some old Mussulman saint ; and making his way up the hillside towards this boulder, he will suddenly come upon a paved causeway which sweeps up over the sand to the rocky summit. Rough flat blocks of sandstone form the paving, and these are only here and there overwhelmed by the drifting sand, though it is evident that the road has been entirely buried at the point where roaches the water.

Mounting to the hilltop, the causeway is seen to pass within a few yards 'of the great boulder, which one now finds to have been surrounded by a rough wall, as though to form a kind of sanctuary or chapel. On the sides of the rock there are several inscriptions recording the coming of various officials of the Empire—tax collectors, superintendents of the Nubian gold-mines, and so on. It is evident from this that the road was used for many a long year after Herkhuf and Sebna had done with it ; though now it possessed for the travelers no terrors, nor did it lead any more to the Land of the Ghosts.

At the point where the causeway passes the boulder the hard surface of the upper desert literally bristles with countless little heaps of stones, each consisting of a small, upright slab of rock, held in place by two or three others. Fragments of pottery indicate that a bowl, perhaps containing water, had been placed beside each pile. Here, then, are the memorials of the travelers who sent out for distant Arthet from the fair city on the island, which may from here be seen floating in the blue waters of the Nile below. These stones are the prayers of those who asked a prosperous journey from the gods of their pity ; from the old ram headed Kimura who lived in the dark caverns below the Nile ; from Satet, the horned goddess whose bow and arrows were the terror of her enemies; and from Anuket with the crown of lofty feathers. For a short distance one may follow the paved road now, as it passes southwards and westwards amidst the blackened rocks and golden sand-drifts of this lifeless land ; but presently it tops a deeply shadowed ridge of rock sand, and so descends into, and is lost amidst, the wide, undulating desert, ablaze with the light of the setting sun.

Travelling in Egypt one sees so many religious remains of the solemn religious ceremonies of the ancient Egyptians, and reading at home one meets with so many representations of the sacred rites, that it is a real relief to come across some relic, such as this highroad, of human energy and toil. In the courts of the temples one has pictured the processions of the priests and the kneeling throng of the people. One has heard in the imagination the rhythmic chants, has smelt the heavy incense, and has seen the smoke of the sacrifice rising to the roof. Glum Pharaohs have stalked across the picture, raising their stiff hands to the dull gods; and rows of bedraggled prisoners have been led to the sanctuary, roped in impossible contortions. One has visited, or has read of, a thousand tombs; and the slow funerals have passed before one in depressing array. But here on this highroad over the western bilk, where the north wind blows free and the kites circle and call above one, here there comes vigour into the heart, these relics of old adventures appeal with wonderful force. Here there are no mysteries except the mystery of the land to the south, and there are no prayers save the asking of a successful journey, and the piling of four stones to the honor of the gods. One does not pace through holy places whispering "How weird!" but stick in hand, and whistling a tune down the wind, one follows in the footsteps of the bold caravan-masters of the past ; and one hanks them from the bottom of one's heart for having played a man's part on their page of the world's history to serve for all time as an example. When the amusements of the luxurious hotels have given out, and the solemnity of the ancient ruins has begun to pall, the spirits of Herbal and of Sabna, of the captains and the the caravan-conductors, are always to be found waiting on the breezy hilltops behind the island of Elephantine, at the head of the Nubian highway.

div.head: Watch Night Service
div.p: A Watch Night Service will be held at All Saints' Church, Cairo, on New Year's Eve commencing at 11:15 P.M.

div.head: British Recreation Club
div.p: The Committee of the British Recreation Club, Cairo, announce their annual ball for New Year's Eve, commencing at 9.30 p.m.

div.head: Quarantine
div.p: Five days quarantine in Egyptian ports has been declared against all arrivals from the coast of Arabia between Lith (south) and El-Wedj (north.)

div.head: Lodge Banquets
div.p: The Bulwer Lodge banquet will be held at the Grand Continental, Cairo. on the 4th prox. and the Friendship's Lodge banquet at the same hotel on February 15th, 1908.

div.head: San Stefano Casino
div.p: On New Year's day the band of the Royal Inniskilling Futiiliers will play on the terrace of San Stefano Casino, commencing at 4 p.m. After the concert there will be a cinematograph performance

div.head: A Xmas Gift
div.p: We are asked by the Maltese Benevolent Society to acknowledge the gracious gift which they have received from the maison Stein in the form of 12 boys' clothing. We are glad to chronicle this new departure and hope that other firms will follow the same good example.

div.head: Zagizig Municipality
div.p: The results of the Zaieazig Municipal elections are as follows : —Emin Pasha Shimmy 195 votes; Mr. Walter Berla 126 votes ; Mr. George J. Choremi 126 votes ; Soliman Bey Ahmed Abaza 98 votes. The first two named were members of the outgoing Municipality.

div.head: The Railway Institute
div.p: A dance given by the Egyptian State Railway Institute was held in the ball of the Institute on Saturday last, a large number of guests being present. Mr. J.C. Crooksefficiently carried out the duties of M.C. The annual ball of this Institute will be held in the large hall of the Institute on the 16th January.

div.head: Murder at Khartoum
div.p: A murder took place last week at Khartoum near the house of Mr. James Currie, the Director of Education. One of his servants having been insulted by another, struck him with a club on his head. The blow proved fatal : and the perpetrator of the crime was immediutely arrested, and is now in jail awaiting trial

div.head: Coopers Hill Dinner
div.p: The Cooper's Hill dinner took place at the Savoy Hotel, Cairo, in one of the private dining rooms on Saturday night. About 20 sat down. Among these were Mr. H.W. Molesworth, Mr G. B. Ireland, Mr. H. A. Humphreys, Mr. R. H. Duke, Mr. F. B. Jacomb, Mr, Mr. N. A. Morton], Mr. L. N. Cooper, Mr. D A. Cardagli, etc.

div.head: Council of Ministers
div.p: The Council of Ministers met yesterday morning under the presidency of H. H. the Khedive at Abdin Palace and approved of the opening of a credit of L.E 3.408,000 to be taken from the reserved fund of the year 1908, of which L.E. 1,916,415 for irrigation projects, L.E. 8,000 for elementary work tar the Cairo drainage, L.E. 100,522 for installing pimps for drinking water in four towns, for illuminating Zagazig and Beni-Suef with electric light, and other towns in the provinces. L.E. 25,300 for the Ports and Lights, L.E. 700,000 for the State Railways and L E. 4'24 763 for various works in the Sudan.

div.head:
Lord Curzon
Return to Public Life
div.p: London, Monday. Lord Curzon is returning to public life and has accepted the nomination to the vacancy among the Irish representative peers created by the death of Lord Kilmaine. He states that his health forbids him to re-enter the House of Commons and he is debarred from entering the House of Lords by ordinary channels by the refusal of Sir Henry Campbell-Bannerman to allow him to take his place with other ex-Viceroys of India in that Chamber.

div.head: Islamism in India
div.p: London, Monday. Nawal Uikarulmulk has been proclaimed the leader of the all-India Mussulmans.

div.head: Egyptian Estates Limited
div.p: An interesting case is shortly to come before the Mixed Civil Court at Alexandria in which the Egyptian` Estates Limited is the plaintiff. This Company sold to various purchasers some lands at Siouf, which had been originally purchased from Soliman Bey Abani, Hassan Bey Abdallah, and Ibrahim Shawish. The purchasers find that the land cannot be taken up owing to the claims of some other parties, so the company is bringing an action against the original vendors, who sold the land as being free from any charges.

div.head: Executions at Alexandria
div.p: We are glad to receive an official contradiction of the report that the prisoners who were executed at Hadra prison on Saturday took eight and a half and seven minutes to die. Three doctors were present and have certified that the execution was carried out in a thorough manner, the deaths being instantaneous. Our reporter was obviously misled by those movements of the body which frequently occur several minutes after death and are due solely to reflex nervous action.

div.head: Fatal Gun Accident
div.p: Our Assouan correspondent telegraphs that a fatal accident occurred yesterday at the barrage to a young Scotch engineer, resulting from the accidental discharge of a friend's gun.

div.head:
The Great Pass
Programme of Inauguration
div.p: On the occasion of the inauguration of the Great-Pass into the Alexandria Harbour on the 30th inst., the following programme has been arranged, weather permitting. H. H. the Khedive will be. represented by H. H. the Prince Aziz Hassan Pasha, accompanied by H.E. Mustapha Ibadi Pasha, Governor of Alexandria, with the Standard on board the yacht "Cohouna". H.M.S. "Diana" will take part in the ceremony as also H. H. Coast-Guard cruiser "Abbas." By invitation the following will embark at the arsenal in steam launches provided by the Ports and Light houses Administration and proceed on board H. H. yacht at 2.30 p.m. The Consular Corps of Alexandria and Chiefs of Administrations. H. M. S. " Diana " will salute the Standard hoisted on board the "Cohouna" with 21 guns. The following will be invited to embark at the Arsenal and proceed on board H. H. S. "Aida" at 2:30 P.M., where they will be received by Murray Bey, Inspector of L. H. The President and Committee of International Chamber of Shipping. The President and Committee of Association' of Importers Alexandria. Representatives of Steamers Navigation Company ( Ocean ) Alexandria. The "Cohouna" will weigh anchor at 3 P.M., followed by H. M. S. "Diana", H. H. S. "Aida", H. H. C. G. Cruiser "Abbas", the Port of Alexandria tender "Teir-el Mina", and the pilot tenders ; and in this order they will proceed out of harbour and through the Boghaz Pass to about a mile to seaward of the Great Pass, thence proceeding through the Great Pass and back into the harbour. When the "Winona" reaches the inner end of the Pass H. M. S. "Diana" will salute the Egyptian flag with 21 guns.

div.head: St. Mark's Alexandria
div.p: The following New Year services will be held at St. Mark's Chute, Alexandria: Tuesday. New Year's Eve: 11.30 p.m. Watch-Night Service. Wednesday. New Year's Day, 1908 8 a.m. Holy Communion, 11 A.M. Morning Prayer and Holy Communion.

div.head: Steamer Movements
div.p: The Moss liner "Manes" arrived this morning from Liverpool via Gibraltar, Algiers and Malta with passengers, mails and general cargo. The Cunard S.S. "Pavia" sailed direct for Liverpool on Saturday afternoon with 3,401 bales of cotton.

div.head:
Egyptian Politics
Kamel's Party
div.p: There was a mass Meeting of the members of Mustapha Pasha Kernel's party in Cairo on Friday afternoon, when the leader delivered a lengthy harangue AU the other parties, which have lately sprung into being in Egypt were severely dealt with and Kernel declared that it was impossible for a party to exist in this country, which would be really representative of the people apart from his own party. He said, "We do not want to boast of our Party. But we tam affirm loudly that the entire nation considers it as the Party of devotedness, sincerity, outspokenness and dignity (sic) and that every other .party is founded merely to thwart and to divide the Egyptians, while bor-rowing some of its ideas." The exordium of the oration deserves re-production. It runs as follows :—"If I were to pass my life in attempting to describe the profound emotion and joy which this meeting produces in me I syould not sue-ceed in expressing all that I feel.s, "'Phis is the first, the greatest and the loftiest patriotic demonstration made by a barge num-ber of Egyptian patriots who have assembled to proclaim to the entire world. "We are the party of hope. the party of life, the party of the fatherland, the party of indepence. Henceforth no sadness for you, beloved Egyp I Henceforth no dejection no despair This n eating is the solid basement on which is erec the independence of our country. The ene les of Egypt deny the existence of the Nati nal Party. But nevertheless it exists acid it w ks ; and I believe it to be my duty to-day o express my cordial gratitude to those riob fri;3nds who have aided me through so ro y years with their suggestions and advice." The thin object of Kernel's hospitality is of course the newly-formed Reform Party of Sheikh Aly Youssef, %Mich, because it does not demand the immediate independence of Egypt, is alluded to by Kernel in these disparaging terms —"It is not possible for the enemies of Egypt to consider the National Party as an enemy of peace. But our enemies scatter abroad these accusations without believing in them, and urge on their creatures, their workmen, and their partisans to continue the work in order to be avenged on us because we demand independence. "This word so dear to us all fires the hearts of our enemies with rage Do you not see that their creatures who demanded independence ten years ago deny to-day that Egypt is ripe for it? "Gentlemen, misfortune can come to us from those of our fellow-countrymen who betray their country, who aid in spreading the accusa-tions of our enemies, and who propagate and exaggerate them, knowing all the time that they are outside the nation, and that they are deceiving their countrymen and obstructing the realization of their fonde-t hopes." After the speeches of Hamel and Mohamed Bey Anis the statutes of Karnel's Party were discussed. Articles 21, 22, 23 and 24 of the statutes deals with the formation of a club. Article 21 says : "A Club will be instituted for the Party in the city,of Cairo. This club may have branches in all the town') of Egypt. Every member of the National Party can become a member of the Club on the payment of L Et, as entrance fee, if he resides in* Cairo and L.E.4 if he resides outside Cairo. These entrance fees are ex-clusive of the subscriptions paid to the budget of the Part)." Article 4 of the statutes gravely states that, "No member of any other Party can be admit-ted to the National Party." . Afterwards, when the statutes), were settled Kernel was elected by acclamation leader of the party. Thirty members proposed by the provisional committee were elected to form the Directory of the Party. The members of the executive committee of the Party include Omar Bey Sultan who holds the important and responsible position of cashier. The appointment of such an eminent authority on finance as Omar Bey Sultan to this important post will, it is believed, carry great weight with native public opinion.

div.head: Pilgrim Season
div.p: Suez. December 28. The total number of Egyptian pilgrims who have left so far for Mecca is 15,000, and about 500 will proceed-by the S S. "Rahmanieh" on Monday next, as compared with 17,000 pil-grims of last year. It is strange to see, that in spite of the outbreak of cholera at the Hedjaz, the pilgrims are taking no notice whatever of the danger awaiting them, and of the qaran-tine restrictions on their return voyage. It is to be hoped that during the return of the pilgrimage the authorities will keep the Afri-can coast near Kosseir well guarded by a coastguard cruiser, in order to prevent the Sudanese pilgrims crossing over in dhows, without performing quarantine, as it has been apparently done several times, and if I am not mistaken the last outbreak in Egypt was imported in a similar way.

div.head: Paris-House Geneva
div.p: M.M. Auberge is exhibiting her models at the Hotel Villa Victoria, Cairo.

div.head:
Cairo Mixed Tribunal
Death of Lateef Pasha
div.p: Sympathetic reference was made in the Mixed Tribunal at Cairo on Saturday to the lamented death of Selim Pemba Lateef, the official president of that Court. Mr. Staico-poulo, speaking for the Bar, desired to express sympathy with the relatives of the deceased and esteem for the character of the lath Presi-dent. Judge Tuck (who presided) replied that he could only endorse the sentiments they bad just beard, recognizing the great services the late Pasha had rendered to the Tribunal. According to custom, the Court then rose for a few minutes. JUDGMENTS. Decisions were given in the cases of Mohamed Kama', Ahmed Ali Dacrour (6n faillita as from June 10, 1907), and Nessim Affifi all of whom were declared bankrupt. HOFIONOVITal v. BRASSERIE DES PYRAMIDES. The judgment given in this case was as follows : The defendants to pay the plaintiff the original indemnity offered by -them, — 3 months' wages amounting to L.E. 30, "ex tequo et boric," together with costs and fees to coun-sel, viz. L.E. 3. JOSEPH KAYAT CO. v. JOSEPH KAHIL AND SOURATI-31658- The Court "awarded the plaintiffs tht,sum of P T. 102 p. 95, the balance still due on the Banque du Caire shares bought of the defendant together with interest thereon at the rate of 9% from October 31, 1907, the defendant taking delivery of the said shares, viz-1000 ordinary and 30 founders'; Sourati, the second defendant, to have his name struck out of the case since it was not shewn that he had authorised Kahn to buy the shares on his behalf. Costs were also awarded to the plaintiff firm to the amount of L E. 700. OTHER DECISIONS In the case of the Imperial Ottoman Bank v. Farid and others, judgment was given for the Bank for P.T. 71,000 and P.T. 300 costs, to be apportioned amongst the defendants. The case of De Vries and Bctutigny v. Malluk and another aroused some interest. It appeared that the plaintiffs, the well known firm of hankers and stockbrokers, bad themselves been sued by the defendant, Malluk, on account of loss sustained by him owing to the retention of certain shares which they held on his behalf and which he had ordered them to sell This action failed and was immediately followed by the present one in which the client Malluk and his associate Ems were sued for the balance owing and co. on their speculative transactions. Judgment against Malluk for L E. 8,000 and interest thereon at 7% from May 14, together with L E. S coats of the action, was awarded to Messrs. De Vries and Boutigny, ELIZABETH L.IS v. MANGE FRERES. This case arose out of certain purchases made by the defendants, the proprietors of the furnishing house, "Au Progress." Me. Ror.4, appearing for Abe defendants, explained that Mme alai% it lady of several aliases, came to Cairo some time ago and rented an establishment, furnishing it lavishly with goods supplied by his clients. The goods in question had not been paid for and execu-tion had been put in on the house (alleged by the Defendants to be a 'maison de tolerance') as also on a dababeab which Mme Lisis had equipped at his clients' expense. As nothing of value bad been found, since the furniture seemed to have been already removed by the debtor, (laughter) the question turned on whether the latter could be treated as a `trader' and made a bankrupt for the amount due. The husband, had never come to Egypt at all and was an Italian subject ; and a consular certificate was the only evidence of the marriage that had been produced. By Italian law, said Me. Rout, a wife can carry on a trade or proles sion in her husband's absence including the maintenance of a 'maison do tolerance.' For the plaintiff who objected to the judg-ment and execution levied against her, it was explained that being a poor woman the consular certificate was the only proof of her marriage she could obtain. No 'certificat de vijwas required, and as to the character of the house the defendants had only to see it and judge for themselves. Besidea this, Messrs. Mange have hitherto spoken of Mme. Mitts as of no procession. (Judge Tuck "It is a disgrace, not a profession"). Judgment was postponed for a week. The conclusion of the case of the National Bank (representing the Cassa di Sconto) v. Trehaki (Mr. Peszhi), Zoucas, and others was deffered.

div.head: The Cairo Season
div.p: Saturday's dance at the Savoy was as usual well attended and much appreciated, the floor being in splendid condition, and the only fault -to be found with the hand being that it did not last nearly long enough to satisfy the dancers. Invitations to the Savoylare always eagerly sought ; indeed applications for thew are so numerous that the management is only issuing a certain nucister for each dance and is exercising a strict control over them and their destination. So it is advisable for all those who in the future receive cards of invitation to be able to produce thorn if called upon to do so. Quite a number of interesting people were to be seen there on Saturday evening. Lady Oppenheimer was .present in black and white, wearing diamonds and a beautiful string of pearls, the Countess Wanda Chamare was gorgeous in a superb gown heavy with dull gold sequins, and with a headdress of golden grapes. She spent moat of the evening with Mr. and Mrs. Macdonald, who are related to the Rockefellers, and Sir Thomas Lipton, whose visit in Cairo is to be but a short one. Crook-shank Pasha was there with MPS. Crookahank and his brother, and Mr. Aspinwall, K.0 , was another interesting personality. Miss Cochrane had been entertaining friends at dinner and spent the evening in the ante-room with her guests. When all the toilettes are beautiful and their wearers possessed of more than their Share of good looks, it becomes an invidious matter to single out any one as the belle of the evening. Certainly the ball room of the Savoy will bear comparison with 'many another in London for smartness and good looks : and the dancing ofthe Cairo belle is second to none. Mrs. Darrell's lovely empire gown of grey with softly colotired embroideries on the corsage was one of the prettiest worn, and Mrs. Appleton's black dress of much the same empire make was much admired. Miss Schulyer Ross was also in black, pailletted, with dull silver embroidery at the neck, and narrow garlands of roses about the sleeves. Mies Taylor was in a soft shade of heliotrope, also empire, weighted with velvet of a deeper Antic, which colour also out lined tho high draped ceinture Miss Rees made a wo!come appearance in pale blue miron trimmed with velvet and with silver fringe outlining the coraage and loosely hang-ing »teems Miss de Cod: was also in pale blue, prettily inserted with laoe over the shoulders and relieved with a big bunch of crimson roses, Miss Luck who is spending her first season here had on a dainty little frock of silk muslin embroidered in pale blue. Miss Chase, a very slender, fair American, looked her best in a plain white satin frock cut en princess°, and slightly draped across the corsage under a masaive buckle. Mrs. Horn-blower was wearing a handsome dress of lace with diamenta berthe, and Mrs. Duffus was also in a wonderfully fitting lace gown and wore a wreath of holly in her hair. Miss Smith also looked well in pink satin, the deep folded bretelles showing a lace corsage. Mrs Peckett was in yellow with pretty golden slippers, and the Miss Coles wore shining shoes of gold with their pretty toilettes of white relieved with bands of blue. Miss Moms wore an ideal frock for the exercise in which she so excels. It was of amber net weighted with many frills outlined with narrow ribbon. Mrs. Carey was chaperoning Princess Irene Duleep Singh and Miss Carey. Sitting in the ball room were noticed Mrs. Royle, Mrs. Joseph, and Mrs de Codt. Among the many, other dancers were Mrs. Scott-Dalgleisb, in black and white, Mrs Maclean in blue, Miss Barnes Lawrence in white, Miss Fox, Miss Plytnpton in green, Mrs. de Cossen in filmy black, Mrs. Molyneux, Miss Froom, Miss Schreiber, and the two youthful daughters of the Senateur Adamoli.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: The Earl and Countess of Rothes, Lady Mildred Leslie, Sir Barington Simeon, Count and Countess von Bernadorft, Mr. Russell Rea, M.P., the Hon. Edith Gibbs, Colonel and Mrs Kincaid, Baron du Buret, and Lieutenant Colonel Eden are among the arrival,' at the Winter Palace Hotel, Luxor.
Prince d'Arenberg, Chairman of the Board of Directors of the Suez Canal Company, who arrived at Alexandria last week by the "Helio-polis" has gone to Ismailia.
M. Dervisie, Chiarman of the Board of Di-rectors of the Paris-Lyon-Mediterranean Railway Company, is arriving at Alexandria this afternoon by the S S. "Schleswig."

The latest arrivals at the Savoy Hotel,Cairo, include Sir Thomas Lipton, Bart, Colonel D.P. D. Neil, Count and Countess de Leusse, Countess Chatcare, Mr. J. Binney, Lady Marjorie Binney, Dr. St. Clair Thomson, Mr. Malcolm-Morrie, Mr. Maurice Ellison, Dr. Pater, Mr. J. J: Duveea and family, Mr. and Mrs. A F. Cress. well, Baron Hewald, Mr. and Mrs. von Meyer-Startzhausen, Mr. Tames McDonald and family, etc.
Mr Edward Dicey, C.B., is arriving in Cairo from London early in January.

Sir John Barrington, Minister Plenipoten-tiary to the Negus, and lady Harrington, have left Cairo for Suez on their way to S Abyssinia. The death occurred yesterday morning at Port Said of Miss Jeanne Dumont, daughter of the Principal Agent of the Suez Canal Company. Many of the ships in harbour flew their flags half mast during the day, as did all the business houses.

Mr Peter Rudolph desires us to express to all his friends, who have supported him in bie charitable work during the year, his regret that he has been usable, owing to feebleness wised by his recent severe illness, to psy them Christmas calls and to extend to them personally the greetings of the season. He entrusts us with messages of goodwill to one and all.

Mr. Rudolph- desires, us sully to thank Mrs Sidney Carver, who, before leaving Alex-andria, made a gift of a sufficient sum of money to provide a Christmas dinner to all the poor under Mr. Rudolph's care.

div.head: Port Said Coal Strike
div.p: Port Said, Sunday. During the last week there has been no change in the state of affairs as regards the possibilities of a settlement of the strike which was started by the bunkering arabs of this port on the 19th. There is no doubt that the strike is in no way caused by the masters un-derpaying the men as after close inquiry and on the basis of payments made during the last few months it is quire clear that the men can easily earn four to four and a half francs per day, which is not a bad wage. Under the cir-cumstances the general opinion is that there is no reason whatever for the masters to ad-vance their tariff. There is a great deed of talk locally to the effect that the men who have been engaged in discharging and bunker-ing have bad offers of employment up country, but the wages are considerably less than what can be earned here, but in spite of this several drafts have left during the week to take up work elsewhere. Coal discharging boats con-tinue to arrive and the old and new basins are now full and to-day four ships have had to anchor outside. Coaling business is going on in the same manner as it has been for the last ten days.

div.head: Commission Municipal
div.p: La Commission municipale s'est réunie le 28 décembre 1907 à 4 h. p. m. sous la présidence d6 es, SChiess Pacha. PtékeiftelM. Ahined Pacha Yehia, J. Bar-bara, É-13enacti, Comanos, L. Escoffier, P. Fondât É. P. Kingham, Mansour Bey Yous-sef, Bàion 'A. de Menasce, Mohamed Bey Mah-fouz, A. Patios Bey, Amb. A. Ralli, D. Rieti, . M. Salvago, E. Stross, Soliman Bey Abani, D. Tambacopoulo, Dr G Valentin, G. Zervudachi, Membres, M. P. Chataway, Administrateur, I. Sidky »est, Secrétaire Général. Le p.-mate-verbal de la Commission munici-pale du 20 novembre 1907 est approuvé. Mention est faite de l'envoi à tous les 'ietn-bru des prit(s-verbaux de la Délégation • di leet 26 novembre, 3, 4, 9, 10, 13,-17 et 23 ekeimbie -1907. ConiitiuniCation est donnée des lettres ci-après de S. E. lé Ministre de l'Intérieur : 1. une lettre du 14 novembre 1907 informant que la construction des nouvelles casernes de la police ne sera pas terminée avant trois mois et qu il ne sera pas possible en cous.'quence d'évacuer les anciens locaux dont le terrain doit étns incorporé -aux parcs nord avant le mois de février. 2. une lettre du 24 novembre 1907 deman-dant de tenir en suspens le vote relatif aux 4ratifications dans l'affaire histone., en atten-dant l'examen des services intéressés. L'Assemblée, après un échange d'idées, déci-de qu'il suffit de constater au procès-verbal que les délais d'annulation prévus à l'art. 19 du dé-cret organique sont expirés et que la décision est devenue exécutoire 3. daux lettres des 26 et 28 novembre 1907 intimait que le projet suggéré par la Com-. municipale au sujet de la promulga-tion d'un arrété ministériel portait réorgani-sation du Conseil du Tenzin), est à l'étude des services intéressés. 4. une lettre de ler décembre 1907 approu-vant les comptes de la Municipalité de l'exer-cice 1906. 5. une lettre du 15 décembre 1907 approu-vant las différents crédits votés par la Com-mission dans sa séance du 20 novembre 1907. 6. une lettre du 16 décembre 1907 informant que eu égard aux raisons exposées par la Mu-nicipalité, le Ministère des Finances pas d'objection à satisfaire au désir qu'elle* ex-primé de voir remettre à quelques mois la question de la consignation du terrain sis à Moharrem Bey qui avait été destiné à la con-struction des maisons à bon marché. Ce Dé-partement croit devoir faire remarqiier que c'est-à titre provisoire que le Ministère réserve ce terrain pour le but sus-indiqué ; si le Gou-vernement venait à en avoir besoin pour une autre affectation, la Municipalité en serait alors immédiatement informée. Il est ensuite donné communication d'une lettre du 19 Déeembre 1907 de M. Abdel Rader Bey Ghériani donnant pour raisons de santé démission do membre de la Commission Mu-nicipale.

Sur la proposition de S.E. le Président, la Commission décide d'adresser à Uhériani Bey une lettre exprimant tous ses regrets et le remerciaut pour la part qu'il a prise aux tra-vaux de la Municipalité. L'Assemblée approuve divers virements de crédits pour un montant total de 448 L.E. pro-posés, par la Délégation dans ses séances des 22 Octobre et 26 Novembre 1907, suivant état comintiniqué aux Conseillers. La Commissiott aborde ensuite l'examen du projet du- budget do 1908; au sujet duquel il est fait mention d l'envoi aux membres du ,rapport de l'administrateur accompagnant sou 'projet de budget, dea procès-verbaux successifs _ide la Délégation exposant les détails de l'étude entreprise par ce Collège et les modifications introduites par liii, ainsi que du rapport du Comité des Finances lequel a adhéré aux pro-positions dé la Délégation. M. Fenderl dit quo l'étude très mûrie entre-prise par la Délégation et par le Comité des -Finances dont les comptes-rendus témoignent de l'attention extrême donnée à chaque article du budget en dépenses comme en recettes dis-pense la Commission de revenir sur cos détails, et ce d'autant pins qu'un *prit d'économie a guidé toutes les décisions dans la mesure qui pouvait se concilier avec les exigences de la Cité. Il propose donc de voter purement et sim-plement le budget. La Commission partage cette manière de voir mais elle échange quelques idées au sujet de certains articles du budget. Relativement aux allocations et tout en approuvant le chiffre, il est constaté que contrairement à la décision prise l'année .dernière certains établissements subventionnés n'ont pas présenté leurs comptes, ce qui aurait pu justifier une mesure de retrait de la sub-vention. Mais la Commission, par bienveillance, veut bien accorder à ces établissemets un délai de trois mois pour présenter leur bilan; jusques-là aucune nouvelle somme ne leur sera remise En ce qui concerne les postes de secours d'urgence de nuit, l'assentblée exprime le désir qu'une publicité étendue soit donnée à ces institutions dans le but de les faire mieux coup/titre par le public. Enfin, le vœu est émis de voir prendre des` mesures pour que à tour de rôle un Rervico de nuit dans ko phannicies soit assuré. Le budget est en conséquence arreté en re-cettes à L. E. 248,450 et en dépenses à L. E. 245,255, avec une réserve de L. R 3,195. Le budget extraordinaire est également ap-prouvé. Un échange préliminaire de vues a lieu ensuite sur la 'question d'une opération de trésorerie proposée, par l'Administrateur en vue de faire face aux travaux extraordinaires et de première nécessité que comportent l'as-sainissement de la Ville et autres besoins.

Etant donnée l'Imporfancentrquestion et v u -11,4ei re tardiee, la goterriiseipapqa - *urne l'exaMen i quintaine et cligge l'Administra-teur, en attendant, de s'aboucher avec les au-torités gouvernementales en vue dé connaître leurs dispositions à cet égard et ide rechercher les moyens financiers à employetipour poursui-vre le programme des travaux' dont s'agit. La séance est levée à 7 b. 1/4 p.m.
4.— RAPPORT DU COMITirepi Minn SUR LI DUO 0111901

Le Comité deafinaneee s'est réuni le 24 Décembre 19074 3 h. p.m. au Palais Muni-cipal pour l'examen du projet- de budget de l'exercice , 908. Etaient présents MM.. E. Benacchi, Prési-dent, II.D. Kingham, Vice-Président, A. de Menasce, M. Salvago et E. Strass, Membres, S.E. le Dr Schiess Pacha, Vice-Président de la Commission Municipale, W.P. Chataway, Administrateur, I. Sedky Bey, Secrétaire (.14 aérai. Il est fait mention de la communication préalable aux Membres, du projet de budget et de la.note de l'Administrateur ainsi que des procès-verbaux de la Délégation relatant l'é-tude entreprise à cet égar4, étude au sujet de laquelle l'Administrateur' donne verbalement les plus amples détails. En ce qui concerne les recettee et après examen des divers chefs, le Comité constate qu'il est en accord avec la Délégation sur les propositions et observations que cette partie du budgetlui a suggérées. Les prévisions sont en conséquence adoptées aux chiffres amendes par ce Collège. Au point de vue des dépenses, le Comit' est heureux de voir que la De.gatiun s'est inspirée de sentiments d'économie qui se sont traduits 1 par des réductions auxquelles le Comité adhère. I Le Comité prend nota -à cet égard qu'en dehors de la création de pestes nouveaux le courant de l'exercice 1907 par suite de la réorganisation de divers services, déjà arrOtée par la Commission, il n'est porté dans le bud-get des dèpenses'du personnel que de légères modifications connuandees strictement pour les besoins de l'admiuistrittion et pour faire face à des promotions exceptionnellement méritées: Pour le surplus, le Comilié adhère aux ob-servations et propositions de la Délégation et exprime le voeu en ce qui concerne la Brigade des Pompiers qu'une rétribution soit imposée aux intéressés chaque fois que les services de la brigade sont requis en vice du sauvetage des effets mobiliers et marchandises, dans les cas d'incendie. L'Administrateur dit que la question est y déjà à l'étude de la Délégation, sur rapport du Comité des Pompiers.

Après un échauge d'idées, le Coir..idopte le chiffre des allocations tel qu'il est proposé par la Délégation, mais il fait 989 réserves quant aux établissements qui ne se conforment pas à la décision de la Commisson tendant à la communication de leurs comptes. En conséquence le budget ordinaire est adopté tel que le propose la Délégation, soit en recettes à L E. 24-4,450 et en dépenses à L.E. 245,088 plus nue réserve de L.E 3,362. Passant au projet de budget extraordinaire, le Comité en propose l'adoption. A ce sujet, il examine la proposition de l'Ad-ministrateur relativement à une opération de trésorerie destinée à faire face aux travaux d'assainissement de la Ville et autres grands travaux de première necceasité. Le Comité estime qu'à la questiOn du compte courant ou de l'emprunt se rattacheCelle des fonds nécessaires pour le paiement des intérêts et pour le remboursement des avances; à cet égard on ne saurait compter d'u'ie façon cer-taine sur le produit des terrains appartenant à la Municipalité, leur réalisation immédiate pouvant rencontrer des difficultés. Il devient donc indispensable de trouver de nouvelles ressources tant pour le service des emprunts futurs que pour les besoins créés par le développement de la Ville, besoins auxquels avec le manque d'élasticité du budget on ne saurait dans l'avenir satisfaire. Sous reserve de ces observations, le Comité est favàrable à la proposition tendant à faire des démarches en vue de se procurer une avance de fonds, pourvu que lechiffre de cette avance soit limité à des travaux d'exécution immédiate, et que dans l'intervalle des négo. citations soient entai es pour élargir les faon'- tés d'emprunt de la Municipalité. La séarwe est levée à 6 h. 1 2 p.m.

div.head: TELEGRAMME HAVAS
div.p: COURS DES VALEURS A TERMS, CLOTURE
Escomptes---Paris 4, Londres 7, Berlin 7 1/2

Owing to the scarcity of orders the Clyde shipbuilders to-morrow will make the biggest pay-off since several years. Even office staffs and draughtsmen are sharing in the wholesale distillment (Reuter)
President Pahieres has received the Duke of Connaught and Prince Arthur of Connaught with military honours. (Reuter)
A complete wireless telegraphy service will be established between Marseilles and Algiers in January.(Reuter)
200 natives, sentenced to long terms of imprisponment for complicity in the rebellion of 1906; have been released. (Reuter)

The Senate has adopted the Navy estimates. M. Thompson, replying to the complaints regarding the falling back of France, said that the position of the Navy must be maintained. Prance must not cease her sacrifices in view of the risk of falling to the fifth or sixth rank. (Reuter)
The Emperor and Empress of Germany have sent the Lord Mayor and his wife as a Christmas gift their engraved portraits signed and framed. (Reuter)
M. Clemenceau denies any misunderstanding between the Government and General Drude. (Havas)

The "Norddeutsche Allegemeiu Zeifung", says that the news published by some foreign newspapers regarding the Emperor William's cruising in the Mediterranean during the spring, his staying at Corfu, and his interviews with other sovereigns, are devoid of foundation, and that no decision has been taken regarding the Emperor's voyage abroad during the spring. (Bauer)
The Senate has passed the budget and the issue of 58,000,000 francs in short bonds required to balance. It has also endorsed the Chamber's taxation of speculative bourse transactions. (Reuter)
Mr. Heir Hardie was driving in a motor car when the latter capsized. It is believed that he has several ribs broken. (Reuter)
850 troops have left for Morocco. (Reuter)
General Lyautey estimates that given good weather, Colonel Felineau will conclude his operations in three days. (Havas)
The "Tribune" announces that General Vigano has resigned, being of opinion that a civilian is better at the head of the army administration than a general. (Reuter)
Senator Casana replaces General Vigano as Minister of War. (Havas)

The King has accepted General Vigano's resignation and conferred on him the Grand Cordon of the Order of S.S. Maurice and Lazzaro. The Senator engineer Severino Casana has been appointed his successor. (Reuter)

During the debate on the war estimates the reporter, M Waddington, said that the two years' service did not produce the expected number of re-enlistments and that he was afraid to mention the amount in the decrease in the annual recruiting. (Reuter)
The Ambassadors have signed a collective note concerning Macedonia. (Havas)
The American Fleet has left. (Reuter)

div.head: THE RETURN VOYAGE OF THE S.S. "HELOPOLIS".

div.p: The maiden trip of the "Heliopolis" from Alexandria to Marseilles has proved most enjoyable A very heavy wind has prevented her from breaking her own record but it was useful in proving the splendid seagoing capacity of this triumph of nautical skill. In beautiful weather, which first greeted the steadier on the other side of the straits ot Bonafacio, the "Heliopolis" steamed into Marseilles at 9 p.m. on Tuesday evening. It is not in the British character to pass without criticism even the most successful and praiseworthy enterprise, it is similarly a British characteristic to keep an open mind until such criticism can be met. Amid the general chorus of praise of the magnificent steamer, 'which has createda new era in Egyptian travel, certain criticisms have been heard and it is our duty as one of the public press not to ignore them. These criti-cisms fall under three beads and we will deal with them accordingly, having taken the op portunity ot the return voyage to investigate their reasonability.

1st. The height of the upper saloon decks which whileadmittedly delightful forpessengers, might, it has been said, possibly be a 'Gauge of excessive rolling or even of a want of stibility. It is a pleasure to be able, once for all, to _silence such a criticism as this. This steamer has been designed by one of our greatest architects and the relative height of the upper works as against the weight under water has not only been carefully calculated but is well within the limit of safety even when reckoned on the calculation for Atlantic weather. It is indeed not as great as many other great linen More than this—theieffect of these high decks is to steady the ship. On the return voyage the "Heliopolis" had had a strong wind on the port bow (a wind which is usually met with at this season in most steamers, to the great discomfort of pas sengera) the enact of. the upper works has been to prevent any roll whatever and the ship has been absolutely steady. Indeed it is doubtful if any steamer afloat would be more steady. in heavy weather than ("travelling more like.a yacht") the effect of the upper works being that of a sail, which was so much used in steadying steamers when both steam and nil were used together. In a heavy head wind no doubt the steamer would be slightly retarded but not as much as might be 'expected. In certain conditions of wind and weather any boat will roll but . the height would always have a tendency to check it.

2. Delay in docking and landing. These were much complained of and were dee partly to the ship's captain making the port for the first time, and partly to the general de-parture arrangement at the Alexandria docks. The first cause will, we hope, be removed on the next trip, but we fear the latter is a long standing grievance. Why are boats allowed to anchor in the water way in this port 1 Why do pilots decline to climb ordinary ship's ladders 1 We hope that Messrs. Strom Whoeare now entrusted with the passenger arrange-ments will prove worthy of so important a duty.

3. Defective serice. Many complaints have reached us as regards the stewards on the ste.stner. It must of course be borne, in amind that starting a brand new line of the largest mid most powerful of their class afloat, with no previous going organization, is a very excep-tional task and good men must always be the result of personal selection, for which there has been no opportunity, but it is satisfactory to know that this defect isfully realized by the managers who statethey will take every means to remove it.
Meantime let us candidly own that their officers, from Captain Holloway downwards, are exceptional men, for the most part spe-cially chosen from the grand old P. and O. service.

The general merits of the steamer have been done justice to in our columns but we should like to pay a tribute of praise to the decorative work of Mr. Collinsor. Todecorate a large number of rooms in many tWeful and beautiful combinations of suitable colours is a difficult task, but few have any idea bow much these difficulties are increased by the exigencies of a steamer, especially the play of light. Mr. Collinson has successfully avoided all crude colouring and several of his effects, parti-cularly the "lounge" (an arrangement in blue and gold with its dainty silk curtains) and the drawing room in green are "chef d'muvres" in their way.

div.head: GYMKHANA AT SUEZ.
div.p: (From a Correspondent)

A most suceessful and enjoyable gymkhana meeting was held on boxing day at the Vic-toria Camp. The ground was kindly lent by the Director General of the Coast Guard Ad-ministration. The various competitions were keenly contested and the competitors were cheered by a large and enthusiastic gathering. For the first race, the Donkey Derby, there were fifteen entries. The riders standing by their barebacked donkeys had to mount at the cord "off" and ride round the course, a distance of 280 yards. No donkey boys were allowed. Mr. Corlett came in a good first. The second event was the high jump, for which there were about eight entries. The winner was found in Mr Willmott, whose name will doubtless be remembered as a frequent prize winner in the Alexandria sports. He was closely pressed by Mr. Tom, the latter failing at 4 9. The next was the market race for ladies. The competitors had to drive their donkeys over a course on which was placed three stalls. At each stall they purchased marked produce which they placed on their donkeys and drove to the winning post. Two well contested heats left the following in the running, dire. Rush, Miss N. Austiok, Miss Beyts, and Mrs. Willmott. In the final Mrs. Willmott came in first with Mrs. Bush a good second. The donkey tug-of-war which followed caused much laugh-ter. Sides of seven, were captained by Messrs. Norman and Walsh. Altera hard struggle lasting some minutes, Mr. Norman's team won. In the next, the Screen Race, twelve competitor came to the post. They had to ride 50 yards, then through a paper screen, having another 230 yards to the winning post. Mr. Austin's Mount, after a scramble in, front of the screen, plunged through, and brought him in an easy winner. The childrens race was the next on the programme. There wore 18 star-ten, handicapped according to site, Master Ahmad Halirn, a younger son of H. E. The Governor, ran well, capturing first place. Miss North Rime was the only girl placed, coming in a dead heat third, with IChalid Hahn; the winner's elder brother. The mental telegraphy race followed. Each lady nominates a gentleman, who runs 100 yards with a sealed envelope containing a message. Opening the envelope he repeats the contents to his partner, who runs to a table placed halfway, writes as much of the message as she CAR remember, and runs on to the finish. The judges after a long consultation declared Mrs. Haydn the.vvinner. The final event, the bucket race damped the persons of the competitors, but not the spirits of the onlookers. The attempts to carry a bucket full of water on a donkey at full speed.. evoked roars of laughter. Mr. Willmott passed the winning poet first, but Mr Taylor, fourth, was adjudged the winner as his bucket contained much more water. One man was seriously handicapped by his donkey imbibing the contents of his bucket be-forethejudge had time to examineit. Mrs.Beyts kindly consented to present the prizes to the fortunate winners. Much satisfaction was felt at the presence of H. E. the Glover nor, who took great interest in the proceedings. Mr. Water-field as the.organizer and able, hard-working secretary, is to be congratulated on the com-plete success of the meeting Great thanks were due to the judges, F 0 Davidson Esq, .M. Altemer, and G. Herbert Esq The success was greatly contributed to by the hard work (af the committee, Dr. Creswell and Mr. Baglehole deserving particular mention. The pari-mutuel was very ably run by Messrs Clemow and Ripen, and the refrealiments were well managed by Messrs. Butler, Owen and Eden During the course of the afternoon the Mabroussa Band played several excellent selections. Now that these gymkhana meetings have been revived, it is hoped that they will be continued.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA TO TANGIER BY RAIL
div.p: In a recent issee says the "Financial News," we mentioned the fact that the French Government are on the point of granting a big loan for public works in Algeria. As a very large por-tion of this grant will be devoted to railway extensions which should be very beneficial to the engineering world, the question of the pre-sent position of the French railway systems in Northern Africa becomes of interest. It is not generally known that in Tunis and Algeria there already exists a network of railways compris. ing about 3,400 millet These, with the ex-tensions provided for in the new project, will make the entire system considera-bly over 4,000 miles. The greater portion of the present system hugs the coast as nearly as the very rugged geological features of the country will allow, and with these reservations we may say, broadly speaking, that the French railways have a complete coast railway service of. some 750 miles in length, or, roughly speak-ing, one third of the north coast of Africa. On the west these lines run right up to the Moroccan border, and we may take it that the grow-ing influence of the French in Morocco will soon bring about a railway from the frontier to Tangier. Recent advices from Egypt show that the Khedive has a private enterpnse for exten-ding the railways of that country westward» towards the Tripoli border, and when this and the Moroccan railway are accomplished the whole of the northern coast of Africa will be *Tanned by a railway, with the exception of that which lies within the tnpoli area. This territory, as being under the Turk, is likely to prove the venous obstacle to the completion of Such a railway; bnt as a complete North Afri-can system will be in the interests of all con-cerned, we have no doubt that the application of outside pressure upon the Porte will some day bring about a railway traversin, Tnpoli trom the Egyptian to the Tunisian boundary, and thus complete a North Affirm line from Alex-andria to Tangier. Reverting to the Algerian railways, a considerable portion of the new loan will be devoted to lines into the interior.

div.head: CAIRO OPERA SEASON
div.p: "LAKME"

Much of "Lakme" was delightful, charming music, excellent scenery and staging, some most attractive singing, and two dances, graceful and sinuous, of the Far East, which to my taste seemed far preferable to the usual tip-toe twirls, and balancing feats : these, however agile and graceful the dancers may be, always seem to me out of all keeping with opera. The story—tragic rather than comic surely—is of the love of a Brahmin priestess for an English officer: her father attempts to kill him, she nurses him back to health and strength, in the forest depths, alone in a world of love ; his duty intervenes and tears him away ; she dies of the datum, poison in his arms. For the performance. one has to confess that there was a certain lack of finish and cohesion; this, as faras the chorus and orchestra were concerned, was evidently due to the impossibility of rehearsing the piece sufficiently After all, it was only apparent at momenta the time was not always exact; the voices, as usual, were full and true, the Choral singing behind the scenes in the last act was surprisingly good and correct. M. Flachat varied he is apt to be throaty and constrained at tithes, but when launched fully into the height of the part, be was at his best, and gave some beautiful not and phrases. Mlle Genevois had some exquisite momenta, especially in certain subdued phrases, where one might say she sang "en sourdine"; one high note especially was a revelation, almost painful, intense ; but, as with Mr. Flachat, there was now and again a hesitation, a certain lack of confidence ; the songs in the second act seemed trying to her. But some of their en-sembls singing was all one could wish and hope .for. M. de Ryk as the Brahmin father washy no means good ; he lacked decision and depth, and contrasted harshly with one's idea of what the part should be. M. (Grins was not so effective as usual ; the part was not forcible enough for him, and in consequence he appear-ed bard and monotonous. But the impression of the whole performance was distinct charm and pleasure, and it all showed that even if the 'light opera' section of the company are not perfect they can give us some most delightful moment-I, and for the rest, are not likely to. spoil the effect of those moments by any but the my slight faults which would probably disappear, had they some experience of some really good schools of opera- which should keep them the whole time up to the standard of their best possibilities.
ZIZINIA THEATRE
"OTELLO."

Verdi's "Otello" is by no means a stranger to Alexandrians, and founded as it is, on Shakespeare's tragedy should be of especial interest to the English people. We see in this drama a grand and true moral picture ; we read in it a profound ethical lesson, for whilst built up to the noblest height of poetry, it rests upon the deepest foundations of true philosophy. With every element of happiness ; manly courage, beauty, truth, devoted love are met together in the persons of Othello and Desdemona who have fought against all the powers of social prejudice in order to become one, and have conquered ; yet all is marred by the fiendish wickedness of one who abuses the resources of a powerful intellect to practice on the open and impulsive nature of Othello, until be crushes in an excess of volcanic pas-sion the jewel which an instant later he would give the whole world to restore.

In the present production at the Zizinia Theatre. Signor Mario Gilion gave us a good conception of the chivalrous Moorish chief, although occasionally he was inclined to exaggerate when portraying the more acute moments of his jealousy and frenzy. He has a tine voice of good timbre., and was very heartily applauded for his rendering of one the heaviest characters on the operatic stage. Signorina Itrusceniski was not quite as successful in the role otitis, innocent and 1:nfortunateDesdemona as we had anticipated, ankfailed to gain the sympathy of her audience until the third act. That she has a magnificent voice is without question, but many of the More delicate and tender passages occurri ng in the first and second acts were considerably marred by being render-ed through almost clenched teeth, a defect which is astonishing in the case of an artiste whose voice has evidently been so highly trained. Her performancein the thirdand fourth acts was however highly oornmendable and received well merited and hearty applause. As the contemptible and villainous Iago, Signor Nunzio Rapisardi was indeed a success. His interpretation showed us mischievousness per-sonified, with the required active delight in the adversity and anguish of others, in keeping with the character. Throughout the opera his splendid voice was heard to great adtantage. The minor characters vere all well supported. A word of praise is especially due to the chorus which exhibits a vast improvement on last season. The hidden chorus was particularly well rendered. We must also congratulate Signor Giovanni Zuccani on the excellence of his orchestra. This opera will be repeated this evening.

div.head: Soolote Anonymo dos Eaux du Caire
div.p: AVIS

Les porteurs des certificats provisoires aux nouvelles actions de Jouissance émises en Juin 1907 sont informés que le solde de la gouscription, soit Prs. 90- Ou P.T. 347,175 par action est payable le ler Janvier 1908.

Les versements devront être effectués au Caire, au siège de la Société, Avenue de Boulaq ouk Alexandrie au Guicbet du Credit Lyonnais où, en méme temps, les certificats provisoires seront échanges contre les titres définitifs.

En cas de retard dans les versements, il y aura lieu de plein droit à l'application de l'ar ticle II des statuts ainsi conçu : Art. II. - A défaut de versement aux époques déterminées, l'intérêt court de plein droit à la charge de l'actionnaire, à raison de six pour cent par an, pour chaque jour de retard. Le retardataire est mis en demeure d'effectuer ses paiements par un avis insére dans un des journaux désignés à l'article 8; cet avis indique les numéros des actions en retard. Paote par l'actionnaire de se libérer dans le délai d'un mois, et sans qu'il soit nécessaire de recourir à aucune formalité de justice, ni d'ajouter à ce laps d'un mois aucun délai en raison des distances, les actions en retard seront vendues publiquement sur duplicata, dans la forme qu'indiquera le Conseil d'Administration, le tout sans préjudice du droit que la Société conserve de poursuivre personnellement l'actionnaire en retard Les titres priinitifs des actions ainsi vendues sont nuls de plein droit. En conséquence toute action qui ne porte pas la mention régulière des versements qui ont dû être opérés, cesse d'être admissible à la négociation et au transfert.
Le Directeur,
ASTLEY P. FRIEND Le Caire, le 5 Décembre 1907.

Medical, antiseptic, used and recommended by eminent dermatoligists in the treatment of ecsema, lepers, psoriasis, ulcerations, skin eruptions, itching and irritating skin humours, baby rashes, etc., also a prophylactic against the risk of contracting disease and infectionus disorders generally. Its healing properties greatly minimize the inconveniences of shaving in cases of pimples, spots, In Tablets price 1/- sold by Max Fischer Alexandria.

div.head: Egyptian Delta Light Railways
div.p: Goods may be booked from this Company's system of nearly 1000 kilometers of line in the Delta to any stations on the Egyptian State Railwas and the Helouan Line. Public Telegraph Messages are also accepted at many stations. For further information apply to the Company's Offices at Cairo, Alexandria, Tantah, Zagazig, Damanhour or Saida Zenab
